snippet: Many of the island’s residents live on narrow streets flanked by enormous stands of phragmites, an invasive grass that burns like tinder.
abstract: Brush fires are a common natural calamity on Staten Island, fed by stands of phragmites, invasive grass found in wetlands, flanking the narrow streets in the area; city, state and federal officials have joined to devise a plan to battle the fast-moving and dangerous fires, focusing on the outright removal of phragmites as a long-range strategy.
lead_paragraph: Many of the island’s residents live on narrow streets flanked by enormous stands of phragmites, an invasive grass that burns like tinder.

headline.seo: A War on Reeds That Feed Staten Island Brush Fires
headline.main: Staten Island Fights Reeds That Feed Its Brush Fires
headline.print_headline: Staten Island Fights Reeds That Feed Its Brush Fires
